title: Daily Evening Bhagavatam Discourse | HH Stoka Krishna Swami | SB 1.10.19 | 05-06-2022
speaker: HH Stoka Krishna Swami

segments.text: Om Agyana Timiran Dhasya Gyanan Janishalakaya
Chaksharon Melitam Yena Tasmai Shri Gurave Namaha
Nama Om Vishnu Padaya Krishna Preshtaya Bhutale
Srimate Bhaktivedanta Svamin Nithinamine
Namaste Saraswate Deve Gauravani Pracharine
Nirvishesha Shunyavadi Pashchatya Deshatarine
Jaya Shri Krishna Chaitanya Prabhu Nithyananda
Shri Advaita Gadadhara Shiva Sadhi Gaurabhakta Vrinda
Hare Krishna Hare Krishna Krishna Krishna Hare Hare
Hare Rama Hare Rama Rama Rama Hare Hare
Om Namo Bhagavate Vasudevaya
Narayanam Namaskritya Naram Chai Vanarottamam
Devim Saraswati Vyasakaya
Dhyasam Tato Jaya Mudirayet
In this session we will be discussing from the 19th verse of the 10th chapter of the 1st canto of Srimad Bhagavatam
Ashu yantashisha satyah tatra tatra dvijeritah
na anuroopa anuroopascha nirgunasya gunatmanah
The meaning of this verse is

who was now playing the part of a human being

at the personality of God is Shri Krishna. The benedictions were fitting in the sense that the
Lord was playing the part of a human being as if a cousin of Maharaj Yudhishthira. Krishna appeared
as the son of Vasudeva who was the brother of Kuntidevi and Kuntidevi's son was Yudhishthira.
So Yudhishthira and Krishna were cousins in terms of relationship but here it is said because
Krishna was
playing the part of a human being though he is not a human being. He is the Supreme
Lord always under all circumstances but he is playing the part of a human being. Therefore
the benedictions were fitting because Yudhishthira is the elder brother of Krishna. So the elder
brother arranges to offer benedictions by the qualified brahmanas
and
the
V effectivement it is accepted which will be offered through chanting of various hymns
to the important guest. Krishna has come to the Hastinapura palace as the guest of Yudhishthira.
So in that sense there it is befitting because Krishna was playing the part of a human being
but they were unbefitting because the Lord is
absolute,
material qualities, material relativities. Now Krishna is described as nirguna, nirguna
means absolute, without any material qualities. So he is not a human being, he has no material
relationship with anybody. So therefore this benediction is not suited for Krishna, it
is only for people of this world who have some kind of material relationships and they
want some benedictions because they may utilize those benedictions
for their material benefit. Lacking those material benefits they may desire some benedictions
which will help them to get some material benefits. But Krishna is not in need of any
material benefit. Krishna has nothing to do with this entire material creation as far
as his activities are concerned or his existence is concerned. Then why does he create? He
creates for our sake.
Why does he create?
And we are foolish to desire material enjoyment while we are entitled to sublime spiritual
pleasure in his association. So foolishly we have turned away from Krishna, foolishly
we seek happiness in material pursuits and Krishna because we are his part and parcel,
we are his own children.
So because we insist, we are adamant Krishna creates this material world and places us
in this material atmosphere, so we can try to enjoy it materially and try to be happy
in this
way.
But intelligent people realize we can never be happy in this material world by pursuit
of material pleasures. We can never be happily.��
we can never be happy so intelligent persons try to find out the real source
of happiness and that is available only in connection with Krishna unlimited
spiritual bliss Krishna is a reservoir of that and in our relationship with
Krishna spiritual relationship not material relationship we can have
unlimited spiritual bliss so it is said here Krishna is nirguna and there are no
material qualities in him that's why nirguna no material qualities but

transcendental qualities, full of transcendental qualities. In the transcendental world there
is nothing contradictory. Whereas in the relative world, the world we are staying,
it's called relative world. And the transcendental world, the spiritual world where Krishna resides
with his pure devotees, that is called the spiritual world, the transcendental world,
the absolute world. There are no relativities. And there is nothing contradictory. But in
this relative world everything has got its opposite. For example,
in this world white is the opposite of conception of black. But in the transcendental world there is no distinction between white and black.
How do you understand this? In the spiritual world there are very very very beautiful personalities,
equally beautiful, even though some of them are of white complexion and some of them are of black.

Since then he has become famous as a thief, but in spite of his being famous as a thief, Makhan Chaur, he is worshipped as a thief by his devotees.
Whereas, in the mundane world, a thief is punished and never praised. In our material dealings, somebody who steals is never praised, is always condemned and is punished if he is caught stealing.
So, why this difference? So, Prabhupada explains, since Krishna is the absolute personality of Godhead, everything is applicable to him and still in spite of all contradictions,
he is the Godhead.
He is supreme personality of Godhead. So, on the one hand, he is described as a thief, on the other hand, he is worshipped as Makhan Chaur.
So, how can these two things go together? That is because when applied to the Supreme Lord, nothing is contradictory when applied to the Supreme Lord.
Because, we should remember, in Vrindavan, Krishna is, why is he stealing?
He does not come to the Supreme Lord. Now, Vrindavan is a little different from Vrindavan.
